Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Minimum dependencies to removed packages and minimum pre-release packages." (#4663) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I don't know which Nuget-repository is correct for this bug, but at least this one has the issues tab.

I own a package called [Owin.Comperession](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Owin.Compression/). It has a following dependency:
`Owin (>= 1.0.0-prerelease && <= 1.0.0)`

And everything worked fine and everyone was happy. Until one day, the Owin-team unlisted the prerelease-version of the package from NuGet. Now my users started to get build errors.

1.0 is still there. Do you consider all pre-release versions are better than release versions?

A repository to reproduce the issue is here:
https://github.com/jomonson/OwinCompressionDependencyIssue

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Minimum dependencies to removed packages and minimum pre-release packages." (#4663) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Minimum dependencies to removed packages and minimum pre-release packages." (#4663) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
1.0.0 prerelease probably never existed but that's not the question here.

The range is >= 1.0.0-prerelease && <= 1.0.0 and there is a 1.0 of owin. 1.0 is clearly higher than any prerelease and definitely smaller or equal to 1.0. So this version clearly matches this range. Why is it even showing a warning (or crashes)?

Commented on issue "Minimum dependencies to removed packages and minimum pre-release packages." (#4663) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We do not have a notification mechanism for package deletion since package deletions are a very rare case. Our package deletion policy is here:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/policies/deleting-packages

Given that 1.0.0 was published in 2012, I don't have any records of whether 1.0.0-prerelease ever existed at all on NuGet.org.

Events.RelatedDescription: Pushed to refs/heads/prefix-upload at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Commented on pull request "README support (rebase, cleanup and polish)" (#4595) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: `Content-Length` header is not required and may contain invalid data, so we can't rely on it to figure out response length. We should probably just try reading first `MaxMdLengthBytes + 1` bytes from the stream. If we end up reading more than `MaxMdLengthBytes` throw exception, otherwise, try converting bytes to string.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Minimum dependencies to removed packages and minimum pre-release packages." (#5882) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@Thorium commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663)

I don't know which Nuget-repository is correct for this bug, but at least this one has the issues tab.

I own a package called [Owin.Comperession](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Owin.Compression/). It has a following dependency:
`Owin (>= 1.0.0-prerelease && <= 1.0.0)`

And everything worked fine and everyone was happy. Until one day, the Owin-team unlisted the prerelease-version of the package from NuGet. Now my users started to get build errors.

1.0 is still there. Do you consider all pre-release versions are better than release versions?

A repository to reproduce the issue is here:
https://github.com/jomonson/OwinCompressionDependencyIssue



---

@joelverhagen commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-328885891)

Thanks for reporting this issue @Thorium. The available versions on nuget.org are 0.5.0, 0.7.0, 0.11.0, 0.12.0, 0.14.0, and 1.0.0. The 1.0.0 version of Owin is the only version that satisfies the version range in your Owin.Compression package. I am not familiar with a 1.0.0-prerelease version of the Owin package. Perhaps it was on some CI or secondary source like MyGet?

Concerning the build failure, I was only able to reproduce a build warning in Visual Studio 2017:
```
warning NU1603: Owin.Compression 1.0.16 depends on Owin (>= 1.0.0-prerelease && <= 1.0.0) but Owin 1.0.0-prerelease was not found. An approximate best match of Owin 1.0.0 was resolved.
```

This warning is just saying that 1.0.0-prerelease was not found so 1.0.0 was used instead. NuGet prefers the lowest version in the dependency version range. Is it possible you have warnings as errors enabled?

As a side note, you can test version range compatibility using this tool:
http://nugettoolsdev.azurewebsites.net/4.3.0-preview4/version-satisfies?versionRange=%5B1.0.0-prerelease%2C1.0.0%5D&version=1.0.0


---

@Thorium commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-329005118)

My customer says Owin.Compression 1.0.16 gives warning but 1.0.15 error, and it's the same dependency.

I have not used CI or MyGet or any other sources than NuGet.org

Why the warning? So should I release a new package for every removed minimum dependency, saying "no changes" in the release notes?

---

@joelverhagen commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-329010617)

> My customer says Owin.Compression 1.0.16 gives warning but 1.0.15 error, and it's the same dependency.

I am not sure why this is happening and have been unable to reproduce the error. Do you have steps?

> So should I release a new package for every removed minimum dependency, saying "no changes" in the release notes?

Yes, that's quite reasonable. 

---

@Thorium commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-329018310)

>> So should I release a new package for every removed minimum dependency, saying "no changes" in the release notes?

> Yes, that's quite reasonable

Ok... How do package owners get notifications of minimum dependencies not being available anymore?


---

@joelverhagen commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-329019074)

We do not have a notification mechanism for package deletion since package deletions are a very rare case. Our package deletion policy is here:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/policies/deleting-packages

Given that 1.0.0 was published in 2012, I don't have any records of whether 1.0.0-prerelease ever existed at all on NuGet.org. 

---

@forki commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-329049163)

1.0.0 prerelease probably never existed but that's not the question here.

The range is >= 1.0.0-prerelease && <= 1.0.0 and there is a 1.0 of owin. 1.0 is clearly higher than any prerelease and definitely smaller or equal to 1.0. So this version clearly matches this range. Why is it even showing a warning (or crashes)? 

---

@joelverhagen commented on [Tue Sep 12 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4663#issuecomment-329049674)

All great questions! Let's move this issue over to the NuGet client repository (https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues) so that the client guys can give all the details. Thanks for all the helpful information!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Documentation recommendations for setting up sources (w/ or w/o auth) for projects that run on CI" (#5881) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Private NuGet feed:
Donâ€™t you just put a nuget.config file in the project/solution? I see a bunch of questions on authenticating private nuget feeds. Iâ€™m assuming we could use buildargs to pass in. 
https://www.google.com/search?q=private+nuget+server+authentication&rlz=1C1CHZL_enUS744US744&oq=private+nuget+feed
http://blog.fermium.io/nuget-server-with-basic-authentication/
https://blog.myget.org/post/2012/12/12/nuget-package-restore-from-a-secured-feed.html

Where do developers learn how to customize a private nuget feed? Is there VS tooling? Or, just docs? 
Iâ€™m also trying to understand how this worked locally and failed in the build environment?

Start of docs:

The recommendation is generally to put a nuget.config at the solution level (or higher up the drive).
There is no tooling to create that, just docs.

And we probably should create something more streamlined in the docs to cover thisâ€¦

From https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/configuring-nuget-behavior:

Project-specific NuGet.Config files located in any folder from the solution folder up to the drive root. These allow control over settings as they apply to a project or a group of projects.


Making your NuGet.config look something like this is recommended (clear, then define your source) as a start.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
    <packageSources>
       <clear /> <!-- ensure only the sources defined below are used -->
    </packageSources>
    <disabledPackageSources>
       <clear />
    </disabledPackageSources>
</configuration>

Then configure all of your sources. If there is an authenticated source, set username and password.

nuget sources add -name MySource -Source http://myNuGetSource -username Tom -password MyPassword -StorePasswordInClearText -configfile c:\nugetExample\nuget.config

(cleartextpassword will work with dotnet.exe restore or nuget.exe restore.)

NuGet.config will end up looking like:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="MySource" value="http://myNuGetSource" />
  </packageSources>
  <disabledPackageSources>
     <clear />
  </disabledPackageSources>
  <packageSourceCredentials>
    <MySource>
      <add key="Username" value="Tom" />
      <add key="Password" value="MyPassword" />
    </MySource>
  </packageSourceCredentials>
</configuration>



Things to improve:
1)	Bootstrapping a nuget.config
2)	ClearText password only on dotnet core
3)	Docs for this general guidance

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Placeholders $product$ and $AssemblyGuid$ not replaced in contentfile through transformation" (#5880) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: I tried this package in VS 2015 with classic library and package.config, it's working, but on VS 2017, it doesn't work in same way. I think this is a regression.

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "`dotnet restore` fails with auth'd (VSTS) package source" (#5874) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: it's actually the same, nuget sends two http requests to two sources(VSTS and NuGet.org here) for fetching the package information at the same time. If the VSTS return first, then you will get the 401 error because it can't find PAT, and if nuget.org return first and it find the package in this feed, then it will just use this one then ignore the VSTS one.

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "VS 2017: PackageType=DotnetCliTool fails to install" (#4190) at NuGet/Home

It doesn't look like AssemblyGuid is allowed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Nuget.exe restore on VS2017 seems to ignore <PackageReference>" (#5870) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@emgarten Indeed you were right!

One .vcxproj references our project and he's missing some uppercase caracters:
``` 
<ProjectReference Include="..\..\..\..\source\anvil\anvilcontrols\Anvil.Controls.vs2017.csproj">
```
When replaced by 
``` 
<ProjectReference Include="..\..\..\..\source\anvil\AnvilControls\Anvil.Controls.vs2017.csproj">
```

The restore works correctly :smile:

I think I had a hard time reproducing in a simple repro case as I was editing with Visual Studio and I guess it was automatically fixing the case when the .vcxproj was saved.

Opened issue "Announcing the NuGet 'Announcements' repo!" (#1) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| ------------- |:-------------| 
| _None_| https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4088|

## Announcing the **Announcements** repo!
As a step towards engaging with the community early on, we have created the **NuGet/Announcements** repo to propose new features and to get early feedback before the team starts implementing these features. This repo will be used for team announcements only. To file a bug or start a discussion, please create a new issue on [NuGet client](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues) or [NuGet server](https://github.com/nuget/NuGetGallery/issues). .

All items posted to this repo are locked, but will typically have links to separate discussion threads on one of the NuGet repos, just like this announcement can be discussed more on this issue: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4088. 
Please use these discussion threads for questions and comments about a particular announcement.

## Receiving Notifications

Subscribe to this repo to be notified about major changes, upcoming features and other noteworthy announcements in NuGet.

![subscribe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/29544263-bea081fa-869b-11e7-9c18-b576890ba049.png)

## Using the Issues list

Use the [Feature](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Feature) and [Breaking Change](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Breaking%20Change) labels to see what's new and changed.

New feature announcements will have one of the following labels:
* [Reviewing](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Reviewing) - Feature being proposed and is undergoing review within the team and the community. 
* [Reviewed](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Reviewed) - Feature has been reviewed and necessary feedback incorporated. The feature is ready to be implemented.
* [Implemented](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Implemented) - Feature has been implemented.
